question: [File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: ServerProtocolVersionResponse] [Integer overflow] Can the version field (u64) be set to values near u64::MAX to cause overflow in version comparison logic or arithmetic operations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: ServerProtocolVersionResponse] [Protocol negotiation bypass] Does the system properly validate that the reported protocol version matches the actual behavior of the peer, or can attackers claim compatibility while using incompatible protocol features? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Epoch manipulation] Can a malicious peer report false highest_synced_epoch values to appear more synchronized than it is, influencing peer selection and potentially serving stale or forked blockchain data? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Version inconsistency] Can a peer report highest_synced_version that is inconsistent with highest_synced_epoch, causing state synchronization errors or enabling attacks that serve data from different blockchain forks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Timestamp manipulation] Can ledger_timestamp_usecs be set to future timestamps to manipulate time-dependent consensus logic or create artificial urgency in block processing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Timestamp overflow] Can extremely large ledger_timestamp_usecs values (near u64::MAX) cause integer overflow in timestamp arithmetic or duration calculations, breaking time-based security mechanisms? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Storage range attack] Can an attacker report lowest_available_version higher than highest_synced_version to create invalid storage ranges that crash state sync or trigger undefined behavior? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Integer underflow] If lowest_available_version is greater than highest_synced_version, can subtraction operations cause integer underflow leading to incorrect range calculations or memory corruption? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Uptime spoofing] Can malicious peers report artificially high uptime Duration values to gain reputation or priority in peer selection, potentially directing traffic to attacker-controlled nodes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Duration overflow] Can the uptime Duration field contain values that overflow when converted to other time units (seconds, milliseconds), causing incorrect peer ranking or selection? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Build information injection] Can the build_information BTreeMap<String, String> contain arbitrarily large or malicious strings that cause memory exhaustion or code injection when processed by monitoring systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [BTreeMap key collision] Can duplicate keys in build_information or specially crafted keys cause hash collision attacks, degrading performance or enabling DoS through O(n) lookup times? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Display impl for NodeInformationResponse] [Information disclosure] Does the Display implementation expose internal node state that could reveal vulnerability windows (e.g., low uptime during restarts) for timing attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Default values] Does the Default implementation create NodeInformationResponse with zero/empty values that could be misinterpreted as valid synced state, enabling acceptance of uninitialized or malicious peer data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [TryFrom: LatencyPingResponse] [Type confusion] Can an attacker deliberately send the wrong response type to trigger UnexpectedResponseError, and are these errors properly handled to prevent panic or resource leaks in error paths? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [TryFrom: NetworkInformationResponse] [Error message injection] Do the error messages in UnexpectedResponseError contain unsanitized input from get_label() that could be exploited for log injection or format string attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [TryFrom: NodeInformationResponse] [Panic on mismatch] Can repeated type mismatches through TryFrom conversions cause resource exhaustion through excessive error allocation or logging, creating a DoS vector? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [TryFrom: ServerProtocolVersionResponse] [Error propagation] Are UnexpectedResponseError instances properly propagated and handled, or can they be silently dropped leading to incorrect assumptions about response types? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Consistency validation] Is there validation that highest_synced_version is actually achievable within highest_synced_epoch, or can peers report impossible state combinations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Ledger timestamp validation] Is ledger_timestamp_usecs validated against highest_synced_version to ensure temporal consistency, or can peers report current blocks with past timestamps to manipulate consensus timing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NodeInformationResponse] [Storage pruning attack] Can a peer report lowest_available_version as 0 when it should be much higher due to pruning, tricking other nodes into requesting unavailable data and wasting resources? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Struct: NetworkInformationResponse] [Connected peers validation] Is the number of connected_peers validated against reasonable network limits, or can peers claim thousands of connections to inflate their network importance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Serde: Serialize/Deserialize] [Deserialization bomb] Can an attacker craft a compact BCS payload that deserializes into an extremely large data structure (e.g., BTreeMap with millions of entries), causing memory exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [Serde: Serialize/Deserialize] [Recursive structures] Although these structs are flat, can future modifications introducing references or recursive types create deserialization vulnerabilities with stack overflow? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/types/src/response.rs] [BCS encoding] [Length prefix manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate BCS length prefixes for the BTreeMap or String fields to cause buffer overruns or incorrect memory allocation? (High)
